title: RL32450
content: More than 53,000 commercial vessels travel the world's waters, regulated by international protocols and U.S. laws to prevent pollution. The maritime industry, including the cruise sector, faces challenges in enforcement and environmental impact scrutiny. Passenger ships make up 13% of the global shipping fleet, with the cruise industry contributing significantly to the U.S. economy. The cruise industry, comprising about 13% of the global shipping fleet, is a significant contributor to the U.S. economy. In 2010, cruises hosted 14.3 million passengers, with over 230 ships in the worldwide fleet. The majority of these ships are foreign-flagged, with Liberia and Panama being popular choices. The industry continues to grow, with new, larger, and more luxurious ships being added each year. The cruise industry has seen an increase in ship size over the past two decades, with vessels now exceeding 1,050 feet in length and weighing over 130,000 tons. These "floating cities" generate large amounts of sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, solid waste, and oily bilge water during a typical one-week voyage, posing risks to human health and the environment if not properly treated and disposed of. The cruise industry generates significant amounts of sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, solid waste, and oily bilge water during voyages, posing risks to human health and the environment. Environmental advocates have raised concerns about the adequacy of laws for managing these wastes, with weak enforcement noted. A 2000 GAO report highlighted issues of cruise vessel compliance with environmental requirements, revealing 87 confirmed illegal discharge cases in U.S. waters between 1993 and 1998, primarily involving oil or oil-based products. The GAO report found that 72% of illegal discharges from cruise ships were accidental, 15% intentional, and 13% undetermined. Cruise ships accounted for 4% of all illegal discharge cases by foreign-flag ships. Environmental groups petitioned the EPA in 2000 to address pollution from cruise ships, leading to investigations and recommendations for waste management. In response to petitions from environmental groups, the EPA studied cruise ship discharges and waste management. A 2008 report summarized waste streams, data collection findings, and options to address ship discharges. The report highlighted the various types of waste streams and contaminants generated by cruise ships, as well as the complex body of international and domestic laws regulating pollution from cruise ships. The report discusses the various waste streams generated by cruise ships and the complex regulatory framework governing pollution from cruise ships. Environmental groups have pushed for stricter regulations, but legislation to control wastewater and other discharges has not been passed in Congress. Legislation introduced in the 111th Congress (Clean Cruise Ship Act, H.R. 3888 and S. 1820) did not progress. Cruise ships produce various waste streams, including sewage, graywater, hazardous wastes, oily bilge water, ballast water, and solid waste, which can harm the marine environment. While cruise ships are a small part of the shipping industry, their waste can pose risks to human health and aquatic life. Sewage, graywater, and solid waste are of particular concern due to the large number of passengers and crew on board. Cruise ships pose a significant environmental concern due to the large volumes of sewage they generate, which can contain harmful bacteria and nutrients. Discharges of untreated sewage can contaminate fisheries and shellfish beds, leading to public health risks. Additionally, nutrients in sewage can promote excessive algal growth, depleting oxygen in the water and causing harm to aquatic life. Cruise ships generate significant amounts of sewage and graywater, which can contain harmful pollutants like fecal coliform bacteria, detergents, and oil. Untreated graywater from cruise ships can have higher levels of pollutants compared to domestic wastewater. This pollution can lead to adverse environmental effects, including excessive algal growth and harm to aquatic life. Graywater on cruise ships, approximately 67 gallons/day/person, poses environmental risks due to nutrient concentrations. It accounts for 90%-95% of liquid waste. Solid waste includes glass, paper, aluminum, and plastics, which can harm marine life if not properly managed. Up to 75% of solid waste is incinerated on board, with ash discharged at sea. Marine organisms are at risk from entanglement with plastics and other waste. Cruise ships generate a significant amount of solid waste, with each passenger producing two pounds of non-hazardous waste per day. Large cruise ships can generate up to 8 tons of solid waste during a one-week cruise, contributing to 24% of the solid waste generated by vessels worldwide. Most cruise ship garbage is treated on board and discharged overboard, putting a strain on port reception facilities. Additionally, hazardous wastes are produced from various on-board activities. Cruise ships produce hazardous wastes from various on-board activities, including photo processing, dry-cleaning, and equipment cleaning. These wastes contain substances such as hydrocarbons, heavy metals, and chemicals that can be toxic to marine organisms if not managed carefully. Oil leaks from engine spaces can mix with water in the bilge, posing environmental risks. Oil leaks from engine and machinery spaces on ships mix with water in the bilge, containing harmful substances like oil, gasoline, and byproducts from petroleum breakdown. These substances can harm marine life and pose health risks if ingested. Bilge water also contains solid wastes, pollutants, and toxic chemicals from engine cleaning activities. Large vessels may have additional waste streams with sludge and oily water mixtures that can enter the bilge. A typical large cruise ship generates eight metric tons of oily bilge water every 24 hours. Large cruise ships generate an average of eight metric tons of oily bilge water daily, which needs to be extracted and treated before discharge. If untreated, oily bilge water can harm marine life when discharged into the ocean, making it a common source of oil pollution from cruise ships according to the EPA. Several cruise lines have faced environmental violations related to this issue. Ballast water is crucial for stabilizing ships, especially cargo ships, by compensating for changes in weight. However, the discharge of ballast water often contains harmful biological materials, including invasive species that can cause ecological and economic damage. This poses public health and environmental risks, as well as significant economic costs to industries such as water and power utilities, commercial and recreational fisheries. Ballast water discharges are the main source of invasive species in U.S. marine waters, leading to public health, environmental, and economic risks for industries like water and power utilities, fisheries, agriculture, and tourism. The economic cost of pest mollusk introduction alone is estimated at $2.2 billion annually. Cruise ships contribute to air pollution through diesel engines burning high sulfur fuel, emitting harmful pollutants classified as human carcinogens by the EPA. Further research is needed to understand the role of cruise ships in introducing non-native species. Marine diesel engines emit harmful pollutants like carbon dioxide, hydrocarbons, and nitrogen oxides, contributing to air pollution and climate change. EPA classifies diesel exhaust as a likely human carcinogen. Ocean-going vessels are significant sources of nitrogen oxide, particulate, and sulfur dioxide emissions in the United States. International shipping is estimated to contribute 2.7% of global carbon dioxide emissions. States and localities are increasingly concerned about the impact of commercial marine vessels on regional air quality. Vessels emit black carbon and nitrogen oxides, contributing to climate change. Environmental pressures on maritime vessels come from states and localities assessing their impact on regional air quality. Cruise ship emissions can have significant local impacts in coastal areas. Shipboard incinerators burn waste, producing ash and toxic emissions. Waste streams on cruise ships are governed by international protocols and U.S. laws, with overlaps and gaps in coverage. The International Maritime Organization sets standards for vessel safety and pollution prevention. Cruise ships flagged under MARPOL signatory countries must adhere to its requirements. The International Maritime Organization's Annexes of the Convention cover various sources of pollution from ships, including regulations for oil, noxious liquid substances, harmful substances, sewage, garbage, and emissions. Compliance with these Annexes is voluntary and requires ratification by sovereign states for binding standards. The International Maritime Organization's Annexes set limits on emissions from marine vessels and prohibit deliberate emissions of ozone-depleting substances. Compliance with the Annexes is voluntary and requires ratification by member countries. The United States has ratified several Annexes, with the flag state responsible for certifying compliance with pollution prevention standards. IMO has established conventions for issues like ballast water management and passenger safety. The United States implements MARPOL pollution prevention standards through domestic laws, including the Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS). In 2006, the Senate ratified Annex VI, regulating air pollution, and in 2008, Congress approved legislation for EPA and the U.S. Coast Guard to implement the standards. The U.S. also participated in international negotiations to strengthen MARPOL Annex VI. Legislation (P.L. 110-280) was enacted to implement MARPOL Annex VI standards through regulations by EPA in consultation with the U.S. Coast Guard. The Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) applies to all U.S.-flagged and foreign-flagged vessels in U.S. waters. The Coast Guard is responsible for enforcing regulations under APPS, which is separate from other environmental laws. Implementation challenges arise from the international nature of maritime shipping, allowing countries to verify compliance and detain non-compliant ships. The U.S. can also enforce MARPOL standards directly. The United States can enforce MARPOL standards directly against foreign-flagged ships for pollution discharge incidents within its jurisdiction. Coordination between agencies is required for enforcement, with the Coast Guard, State Department, and flag states involved. No single agency oversees all functions related to cruise ships in U.S. waters, with the Coast Guard, EPA, and Department of Justice playing key roles. The U.S. government agencies responsible for regulating cruise ship discharges include the Coast Guard, EPA, Department of Justice, Department of State, NOAA, and APHIS. The Clean Water Act is the main law governing pollution in U.S. waters. States and localities also have some responsibilities in this area. The Clean Water Act is the principal U.S. law for limiting polluting activity in water bodies. The National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) program controls pollutant discharges, including from vessels. Sewage discharges from cruise ships are exempt from NPDES permits but are prohibited from being dumped untreated into U.S. navigable waters within 3 miles of shore under Section 312 of the Clean Water Act, enforced by EPA and the Coast Guard. Under Section 312 of the Clean Water Act, vessels are prohibited from discharging untreated sewage into U.S. navigable waters within 3 miles of shore. This includes cruise ships, which must have marine sanitation devices (MSDs) to prevent untreated sewage discharge. The EPA sets performance standards for MSDs, while the Coast Guard regulates MSD design and operation. Large vessels, like cruise ships, use Type II or Type III MSDs. Type II MSDs treat waste before discharge, meeting specific limits, while Type III MSDs store waste for later disposal. Beyond 3 miles, raw sewage can be discharged. The regulations for marine sanitation devices (MSDs) require treated waste discharge within specific limits. Type III MSDs store waste for later treatment, while Type I MSDs disinfect sewage before discharge. Critics highlight deficiencies in the regulations, as they only cover bacterial contaminants and suspended solids, neglecting other pollutants like chemicals and heavy metals released by cruise ships. The NPDES permit program regulates a wider range of pollutants from point sources, including chemicals, pesticides, heavy metals, oil, and grease, in addition to bacterial contaminants and suspended solids. Coast Guard enforcement of MSD rules has been criticized for lacking thorough inspections of sewage treatment equipment on cruise ships. The Coast Guard faces challenges in detecting environmental violations on cruise ships due to focus on safety, large ship size, limited time and staff, and lack of surprise in inspections. Resources have shifted towards homeland security post-9/11, reducing time for vessel inspections. Annex IV of MARPOL regulates sewage discharges from ships, requiring sewage treatment plants, comminuting systems, or holding tanks on cruise ships. Annex IV of MARPOL regulates sewage discharges from vessels, requiring sewage treatment systems or holding tanks. The requirements are minimal, with no specific performance standards prescribed. Vessels must treat sewage within three miles of shore with a certified system, and between three and 12 miles with maceration or chlorination. Discharges beyond 12 miles are unrestricted, with the option to meet less stringent requirements in certain jurisdictions. In U.S. waters, cruise ships and other vessels must comply with regulations implementing Section 312 of the Clean Water Act. Some cruise ships use Advanced Wastewater Treatment (AWT) systems for sewage treatment, which are effective in removing various substances. Section 312 also establishes no-discharge zones for vessel sewage to protect the environment. No-discharge zones (NDZs) can be established by states to prohibit the discharge of sewage from vessels into certain waters to protect the environment. States must apply to the EPA under three categories for NDZ designation, based on environmental protection needs and the availability of pumpout facilities. NDZs have been designated in 26 states, including inland states, for various reasons such as protecting environmentally sensitive areas like shellfish beds or coral reefs. No-discharge zones (NDZs) can be established by states to prohibit sewage discharge from vessels into specific waters for environmental protection. Cruise ship discharges of solid waste are governed by the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act. The Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act (MPRSA) regulates the disposal of materials at sea for cruise ships and other vessels. It prohibits the transportation of garbage for dumping without a permit and dumping materials into U.S. territorial seas or ocean waters. EPA issues permits for sea disposal, excluding dredged material handled by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Cruise ships are not required to have an MPRSA permit for solid waste discharge beyond U.S. jurisdiction. The Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) also applies, prohibiting garbage discharge within certain distances from shore and plastic discharge anywhere. The Act to Prevent Pollution from Ships (APPS) prohibits garbage discharge within specific distances from shore and plastic discharge anywhere, applying to all vessels in U.S. navigable waters and the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). The Coast Guard administers APPS, conducting inspection programs to ensure port facilities can handle offloaded solid waste. EPA has reported discharges of solid waste and plastic from cruise ships, prompting potential amendments to MARPOL Annex V. Options to address solid waste from cruise ships include enhancing on-board garbage handling technologies, implementing stronger waste management plans, and expanding port reception facilities. The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) governs hazardous waste management, imposing requirements on generators, transporters, and facilities. Hazardous waste is defined by its characteristics or appearance on specific lists. Treatment facilities must have permits and comply with EPA regulations. The cruise ship industry must comply with RCRA regulations for hazardous waste management, including proper identification, storage, and disposal of hazardous wastes generated onboard. Activities such as cleaning, painting, and passenger services can result in the generation of hazardous wastes that must be offloaded for recycling or disposal in accordance with RCRA. Cruise ships must comply with RCRA regulations for managing hazardous waste generated onboard, including from activities like cleaning, painting, and passenger services.
